Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Làbákẹ́ ti Sènábù kúrò lọ́nà, ó wọ yàrá rẹ̀, ó sì ti ilẹ̀kùn lẹ́yìn.

Soon the sharp cry of a soul in torment came from inside the room - lasting for some three minutes, stopping for some two minutes only to pick up again like the slow, on-and-off pain of guinea worm, Ceasing and picking up, picking up and ceasing.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Nígbà tó yá, igbe ẹkún ọkàn tíì yà ń jẹ wá láti inú yàrá – ó pẹ́ fún ìṣẹ́jú mẹ́ta kan, ó dáwọ́ dúró fún bí ìṣẹ́jú méjì kan, ó tún bẹ̀rẹ̀ bí ìrora sò bìà, bí óṣe máa ń dun ni, tí á tún rowọ́.

Ceasing temporarily. Then ceasing finally when sleep overtook the eyelids.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Á dáwọ́ dúró díẹ̀. Lẹ́yìn náà, ó ń dáwọ́ dúró pátápátá nígbà tí oorun ti ń kún ojú rẹ̀.

I'll not sleep today', she moaned, I'll not close my eyes.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Mi ò ní í sùn lónìí, ó gbin, “Mi ò níí di ojú mi.

I'll be sitting down like this, he'll meet me sitting down like this.. waiting. Waiting...
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Màá jókòó báyìí, á bá mi lórí ìjókòó báyìí...mo ń dúró...mò ń dúró...

And truly, Labake did not close her eyes – even when the night was so far spent.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Lóòótọ́,  Làbákẹ́ kò dijú rẹ̀ – títí mọ ìgbà tí ilẹ̀ ti ṣú dáadáa.

She heard the distant sound of the amplifier, blaring fuji music at some night party in the heart of the town.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ó gbọ́ ohùn orin fújì láti ọ̀nà jíjìn, ní ibi ìnáwó kan ní ìgboro ìlú.

Labake listened, after some time, the music seized. The revelling had stopped.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Làbákẹ́ tẹ́tí, lẹ́yìn ìgbà díẹ̀, orin náà kò dún mọ́. Ariwo rẹ̀ lọlẹ̀.

Hundreds of naira – even thousands - had gone down the drain!
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ọgọọgọ́rùn-ún náírà - títí mọ́ ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún - ló ti ṣòfò.

Silence now lay upon the whole city, the air was old and still.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìdạ́kẹ́ rọ́rọ́ wá wà ní gbogbo ìlú, afẹ́fẹ́ náà tutù, ó sì dákẹ́ rọ́rọ́.

What broke the stillness now was the intermittent sound of the whistle of the night watchmen and the konleogbele sound of their bells.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Nǹkan tí ó da ìdákẹ́ rọ́rọ́ náà láàmú ni ariwo lemọ́ lemọ́ fèrè àwọn ọlọ́dẹ àti ohùn kó-ń-lé-ó-gbé-lé agogo wọn.

The wall clock continued ticking away, it was now two o'clock in the morning. The sound of the alarm watch blare's ears, she came to the sitting room and sat down.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Aago ń lọ, ó ti wá di aago méjì géérégé lówùúrọ̀. Ohùn aago ìdágìrì dé etí Làbákẹ́, ó wá sí yàrá ìgbàlejò ó sì jókòó.

Her eyes gazed intently at the door resolving she would take Alamu up on several issues the very minute he showed his face in the house.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ó tẹjú mọ́ ilẹ̀kùn pẹ̀lú ìpinnu pé òun á bá Àlàmú fa oríṣìíríṣìí ní ìṣẹ́jú tí ó bá fojú hàn nínú ilé.

Alamu had to satisfy her with a concrete explanation on all those things she had heard from people from neighbours, from his friend and from the mammy-wagon driver.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àlàmú ní láti tẹ́ ẹ lọ́rùn pẹ̀lú àlàyé tó dán mọ́rán lórí gbogbo nǹkan tí ó gbọ́ lẹ́nu àwọn èèyàn – àwọn aládùúgbò, lẹ́nu ọ̀rẹ́ rẹ̀ àti awakọ̀ọkọ̀-akẹ́rù náà.

His life had become one bundle of mystery to her and it was, Alamu alone who could interprete the mystery.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ayé Àlàmú wá jẹ́ àdììtú sí i, Àlàmú nìkan ló sì lè tú u.

His life had become one big knot and it was he alone who could untie it. That he had to do the very moment he stepped into the house.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ayé rẹ̀ ti di kókó ńlá kan tí wọ́n so pa tí ó sì jẹ́ pé òhun nìkan ni ó lè tú u. Ìyẹn ni ó ní láti ṣe ní kété bó báṣé ń wọlé.

Labake had seen a lot of things herself – factual and reasonably authentic.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Làbákẹ́ ti rí oríṣìíríṣìí nǹkan fún rarẹ̀ – tí ó jẹ́ kókó tí ó sì jẹ́ ògidì.

What explanation would Alamu give to them all? The explanation must be so convincing, so persuading to satisfy her.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àlàyé wo ni Àlàmú yóò ṣé sí gbogbo rẹ̀? Àlàyé náà gbọ́dọ̀ lè yíni lọ́kàn padà, kí ó lè tẹ́ ẹ lọ́rùn.

She wondered what further role Alamu's friend was going to play in the matter.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ó wòye irú ipa tí ọ̀rẹ́ Àlàmú á tún fẹ́ kó nínú ọ̀rọ̀ náà.

How effectively were they going to handle the matter of the mother-in- law?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Báwo ni wọ́n ṣe fẹ́ gba ọ̀rọ̀ ìyá ọkọ rẹ̀ mú?

For an immediate query, where had Alamu gone to?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Fún ìdáhùn kíákíá, níbo ni Àlàmú  lọ?

Why did he spend the night there?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Kí ló sì fà á tí ó fi sun ibẹ̀ mọ́jú?

Why did he refuse to let her know before hand that he would keep the night outside?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Kíni ìdí tí kò fi sọ fún un tẹ́lẹ̀ pé òun á sùnta?

It was the early-morning drum signal on a neighbour's radio set which answered her questions.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ohùn ìlù òwúrọ̀ kùtùkùtù orí rédíò aládùúgbò kan ló dáhùn ìbéèrè rẹ̀.

A not too-satisfying answer merely indicating the arrival of dawn.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìdáhùn tí kò tẹ́ni lọ́rùn tó ń sọ pé ilẹ̀ ti mọ́.

Labake's head ached badly, she felt pain all over the body and yawned.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Orí fọ́ Làbákẹ́ gidi, ara ń ro ó, ó sì yán.

Was this what they called suffering for the sake of love?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ṣé nǹkan tí wọ́n ń pè ní ìjìyà ìfẹ́ rè é?

Love must be a giddy thing indeed to make one suffer so much like this.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìfẹ́ wá jẹ́ nǹkan gidi kan tó ń mú èèyàn jìyà báyìí.

The city at dawn! Everything was alive again.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìlú ńlá ní dàájí! Gbogbo nǹkan ti tún jí sáyé.

The sleeping giant has woken up! The hustle and bustle of city life had started as usual.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Òmìrán tó ń sùn ti jí! Ìgbòkègbọdọ̀ ìlú ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ bí ó ṣé máa ń wáyé.

The city people, like frightened ants, hurried away to their various places of work.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àwọn ará ìlú tètè ń gbọ̀nà ibi iṣẹ́ wọn lọ, bí ikòkòrò tẹ́rù ń bà.

It was work, work and work for them all. Work and quench!
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Iṣẹ́ iṣẹ́ iṣẹ́ ṣáà ni fún gbogbo wọn. Iṣẹ́ àti ìyá.

The bus stops were crowded.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àwọn ìbùsọ-ọkọ̀ ni ẹ̀rọ̀ kún bámú.

Getting inside the city buses  was a battle - survival of the fittest forty nine sitting, ninety nine standing!
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Rírí ọkọ̀ ìlú wọ̀ wá dogun – ẹni yára lòògùn ń gbè – “èèyàn mọ́kàndínláàádọ́ta ní jokòó, èèyàn mọ́kàndínlọ́gọ́rùn-ún nídùúró!”.

The pregnant women fought it out with the same zeal and energy as the teenage girls rushing to school struggling to beat lateness.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àwọn aboyún ń jìjà gbara pẹ̀lú okun, bẹ́ẹ̀ náà làwọn ọmọbìnrin tó ń kánjú àtidé ilé-ìwé ki wọ́n má pẹ̀ ẹ́.

And the able-bodied young men demonstrated their agility by crashing inside the city buses through the small windows of the vehicle!
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ati àwọn ọ̀dọ́mọkùnrin tó dá ṣáṣá tí wọ́n ń fi agbára wọn hàn nípa bíbẹ́ wọnú ọkọ̀ láti ojú fèrèsé kéé-kèè-kééọkọ̀!

In Labake's area of the town, the local hawkers had started advertising their commodities in sing- song, sonorous voices.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ní apá àdúgbò Làbákẹ́ nílùú náà, àwọn oníkiri ń polówó ọjà wọn ní ohùn orin, ohùn dídùn.

A group of young boys and girls had gathered round the small stall in front to purchase the rice and tuwo which had started boiling hot inside the pots on the fire - a look of expectancy on their faces.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ọ̀wọ́ àwọn ọmọkùnrin àti ọmọbìnrin kéé-kèè-kéé kan ti yí ìsọ̀ kan ká níwájú láti ra ìrẹsì àti túwó tí ó ti ń hó nínú ìkọ̀kọ̀orí iná – wọ́n ń retí kó jinná kíá.

Labake stretched her legs and came out to the verandah of their house.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Làbákẹ́ na ẹsẹ̀ rẹ̀, ó sì jókòó sí ìta ilé wọn.

The local seamstresses were already on their way to their various shops.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àwọn aránṣọbìnrin ìbílẹ̀ náà ti wà lọ́nà ìsọ̀ wọn.

They balanced their sewing machines on the head with accustomed ease, chattered all along about this and that topic, connected with their trade...
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Wọ́n gbé maṣíìnì ìránṣọ wọn sórí pẹ̀lú ìrọ̀rùn lọ́nà tó ti mọ́ wọn lára, tí wọ́n sì ń tàkùrọ̀sọ lórí oríṣìíríṣìí nǹkan tí ó jẹmọ́ òwò wọn...

Labake too used to be a good seamstress and very creative too. She could design garments, even now, to match the latest trends in fashion.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Làbákẹ́ náà jẹ́ ránṣo-ránṣo gidi tí ó sì mọṣẹ́ dáadáa. Ó lè dárà sí ẹ̀wù, pàápàá báyìí láti bá ìgbà mu.

While in England, she took some courses in sewing and designing.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Nìgbà tó ṣì wà ní Englandi, ó kọ́ ẹ̀kọ́ nínú ìránṣọ àti ìdáràsí.

This in addition to her core course which was modelling, it had not been possible for her to practise her trade here in the country, straight away, because of people's general apathy to it.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Èyí kún ẹ̀kọ́ rẹ gan an tí ó jẹmọ́ oge, kò ṣeésé fún un láti ṣé òwò rẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-èdè yìí lẹ́sẹ̀kẹsẹ̀ nítorí ẹ̀rọ̀ gbogbo ògbò àwọn ènìyàn nípa rẹ̀.

Otherwise, like these seamstresses, she too would by now have been on her way to her place of work.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Bí bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́, bí i àwọn aránṣọbìnrin yìí, òun  náà ìbá wà lọ́nà ibiṣẹ́ tirẹ̀ báyìí.

For now, she was a full time housewife.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ṣùgbọ́n ní àkókò yìí, ìyàwó ilé tí kò níṣẹ́ àṣejẹ ni.

Labake took her eyes away from the seamstresses, who had negotiated the comer of the street.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Làbákẹ́ gbójú rẹ̀ kúrò lọ́dọ̀ àwọn aránṣọbìnrin náà, tí wọ́n ti ń bọ́ sí kọ̀rọ̀ òpópónà náà.

She yawned, she was, understandable, not feeling comfortable, her limbs were stiff, her eyes were drowsy. She felt like that housewife who went through the ordeal of pounding five yam-filled mortars the previous day, all alone, for some late-night visitors.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ó yán, ara kò rọ̀ ọ́rárá, apá rẹ̀ yi, òòyì ń kọ́ ojú rẹ̀. Ó ń ṣe é bí i ti ìyàwó ilé tí ógún iyán ẹ̀kún odó márùn-ún lánàá fún àwọn àlejò aláfòruwọ̀lú.

Her ribs and joints ache like that of a boxer who had just survived twenty gruelling rounds in a fight of the century! She stumbled inside again.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ihà rẹ̀ àti oríkèéríkèé ara ń ro ó bí i ti ajẹ̀ṣẹ́ tí óṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ yege ìjà lọ́nà ogún nínú ìdíje ìjà sẹ́ńtúri! Ó tún bẹ́ wọlé.

Zenabu was already in the Sitting room, standing at attention by the side of a small mound, something wrapped up inside a blue pillow case, placed in a plastic bucket.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Sènábù ti wà ní yàrá ìgbafẹ́, ó dúró ṣinṣin sí ẹ̀gbẹ́ òkìtì kékeré kan, nǹkan tí wọ́n dì sínú aṣọ ìrọ̀rí búlúù tí wọ́n gbé sínú garawa oníke.

I am ready to go now ma.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Mo ti fẹ́ máa lọ nísinsìnyí mà.

Labake took a cursory look at the small figure in front of her.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Làbákẹ́ wo kiní kékeré iwájú rẹ̀ láwòfín.

Yes, it was Zenabu, wanting to go, and taking permission from her.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, Sènábù ni, ó fẹ́ máa lọ, ó sì ń tọrọ ààyè lọ́wọ́ rẹ̀.

Go where, Zenabu? Go home ma.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ibo lò ń lọ Sènábù? Mò ń lọ ilé mà.

Home? Where? In Kwara.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ilé? Níbo? Ní Kwárà.

Kwara? Yes. Kwara, My home ma.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Kwárà? Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, Kwárà, ilé mi mà.

Why? What's wrong with you Zenabu?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Kílódé? Kí ló ṣé ọ́ Sènábù?”

Nothing madam
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Kò sí nǹkankan Màdáámú

Come on Zenabu! What is it?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Sọ̀rọ̀ Sènábù! Kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀ ?

Em... em... Nothing... Nothing madam.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ẹm... ẹm... Kò sí... Kò sí màdáámú.

Are you crazy! Are you mad!
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ò ń ṣièrè ni! Ṣó o ya wèrè ni!

Zenabu's cheeks wrinkled, her brows tensed and she closed her eyes.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ́ Sènábù hunjọ, irun ojú rẹ̀ yi, ó sì dijú rẹ̀.

She soon opened them again and the tears came in beads chasing one another down her little cheeks.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ó tún ṣí ojú rẹ̀, omijé sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í dà wá lẹ̀ bí i ìlẹ̀kẹ̀ ní tẹ̀lé-ǹ-tẹ̀lé sẹ́ rẹ̀kẹ́ rẹ̀ kékeré.

Madam. Madam, she sobbed out, "That's what. what they say you are."
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Màdáámú...màdáámú, óké jáde, “Nǹkan tí wọ́n ló ń ṣe yín nìyẹn”.

"What? They say that em... em.. that.. that you are crazy madam.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Kíni? Wọ́n sọ pé ẹm... ẹm... pé... pé ẹ ti ya wèrè màdáámú.

Me? Who told you that?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Èmi? Ta ló sọ bẹ́ẹ̀ fún ọ?

People in the other house.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àwọn ará ilé kejì.

Zenabu pointed her finger towards the houses around them.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Sènábù na ìka ọwọ́ rẹ̀ sí àwọn ilé tó wà lá yìí ká wọn.

They say my madam has gone mad, they say my master has gone mad too, they say my madam has gone crazy, they say I am living inside a mad house. The people there said it... Zenabu pointed her finger again.

Neighbours! These illiterate neighbours!

These packs of ignorant, illiterate neighbours.

Me? Yes, madam

No, madam. What then?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Rárá, màdáámú. Kí wá ni?

They said you will tear my flesh... with your teeth... in the night.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Wọ́n ní ẹ máa fi eyín ya ẹran ara mi... ní alẹ́.

After I am asleep, they said you will not sleep on the day you will do it.

But that you will wait until I had slept off well.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n ní ẹmá a dúró di ìgbà tí mo bá ti sùn wọra.

Then you will grab me. Because you have gone mad.

Zenabu... Zenabu. You can't understand why I stayed awake all through the night till this morning. You are too young to know why

Madam, the people told me why. Will you stop!
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Màdáámú, àwọn èèyàn náà sọ ìdí rẹ̀ fún mi. Ṣé wà á dẹ́kun!

Madam, I have packed my load.

And? And I am going back home.

You are running back home - no doubt - from a mad woman?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ò ń sá lọ ilé - láìsí àní-àní - ò ń sáfún wèrè obìnrin àbí?

No, madam. What then?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Rárá, màdáámú. Kí wá ni?

Just going back home...to my father and mother.

Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Sènábù tún gún èjìká ó dẹ̀ mirí tàfojúdi tàfojúdi, omijé ojú rẹ̀ ti gbẹ tán pátápátá.

Labake was a bit scared. Was this little girl mad?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Èrù ba Làbákẹ́ díẹ̀. ṣé ọmọ kékeré yìí ya wèrè ni?

She really must be mad. It would be better to allow this little wretch of a housemaid have her way.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Á jẹ́ pé ó ti ya wèrè. Á dáa kí ó jẹ́ kí ọmọ-ọ̀dọ̀ òsì yìí rọ́nà lọ.

See her looking impudently. See her pouting her small lips. See fire inside her small eyes.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ẹ wò ó bí ó ṣé ń wò, tàfojúdi tàfojúdi. Ẹ wò bí óṣe ń ṣu ẹnu pọ̀. Ẹ wo iná lójú rẹ̀ kékeré.

Alright Zenabu', Labake said piping down, 'You can go to your home town... You are released.

Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Sènábù gbé ẹrù rẹ̀ kékeré sílẹ̀, ó sì nawọ́ rẹ̀. Ó fẹ́ gba owó-oṣù rẹ̀ tókù, àti owó ọkọ̀ rẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ màdáámú.

Alright.. I will wait for master.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ó dáa... Màá dúró de ọ̀gá.

Ok Zenabu, that's right, wait for him, go and stay in your room till master comes back?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ó dáa Sènábù, ìyẹn dára, dúró dè é, lọ dúró nínú yàrá rẹ títí ọ̀gá á fi padà dé?

No! No! I will stay here! I will stand here like this, till master will come. He will meet me here.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Rárá! Rárá! Màá dúró níbí! Màá dúró báyìí, títí ọ̀gá máa fi dé. Wọn á bá mi níbí.

Labake smiles to herself, this girl had thoroughly gone mad... Let her remain standing there, Labake yawned loud. She stood up and staggered towards her own room propping Tinu to her chest, she had become badly spent.

Really intoxicated with sleep. Nature would not be cheated

How was Alamu going to thank his friend enough for what he had done to assist him these past nine months that he'd been in trouble, burning hell, hell on earth.

Two hours ago, Adio was sweating it out in court on behalf of his friend.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Wákàtí méjì sẹ́yìn, Àdìó ńṣe àwíjàre ọ̀rẹ́ rẹ̀ nílé ẹjọ́.

That was the third time he would argue Alamu's case.

There were no queries for him. What about warnings?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: A kò béèrè rí. Ìkìlọ̀ ńkọ́ ?

Two times. Where is the evidence?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ẹ̀ẹ̀mejì. Ẹrí dà?

Were they written warnings? No Verbal. Mr. Personnel Manager, did you say you set up a probe  panel?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ṣé ẹ kọ wọ́n sílẹ̀? Rárá, àfẹnusọ ni. Ọ̀gbẹ́ni alábòójútó òṣìṣẹ́, ṣé ẹ ní ẹ dá ìgbìmọ̀ ìwádìí sílẹ̀?

Yes. To do what? Give us the paper containing its terms of reference.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni. Láti ṣé kíni? Ẹ fún wa ní ìwé tí ì júwe iṣẹ́ wọn wà.

No paper. I just told the panel to... to... to...
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Kò sí ìwé. Mo kàn sọ fún àwọn àjọ náà pé kí...kí...kí...

Was the proceeding during the probe tape recorded?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ṣé ẹ gba ohùn sílẹ̀ nígbà tí wọ́n ṣè pàdé ìgbìmọ̀ ìwádìí náà?

No, it was not. You merely paraphrased evidence at the probe in black and white?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Rárá, a kò gbà á. Ṣé ẹ kàn ṣé àgékúrú ìwádìí yín lásán ni?

Yes. I put it to you that Alamu's evidence at the probe was taken under duress.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni. Mò ń sọ pé ìwádìí yin gba ọ̀rọ̀ lẹ́nu Àlàmú tipátipá.

You stage-managed the probe Mr. Personnel Manager - secretly nosing round members of the panel, intimidating them with threats.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ẹ kàn ṣé ìwádìí arúmọjẹ ni alákòóso òṣìṣé - tí ẹ kàn ń fimú kó pàǹtí kiri láàrin àwọn ọmọ ìgbìmọ̀ aṣèwádìí, ẹ sì ń halẹ̀ mọ́ wọn.

You no longer can deny this because we have shown the court evidence to prove this.’ Lawyer Adio now turned to the learned Judge.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ẹ ò lè sẹ́ èyí torí a ti fi gbogbo èrí tó gbe èyí lẹ́sẹ̀ hàn nílé ẹjọ́. Agbẹjọ́rò Àdìó sì kọjú sí adájọ́ tó mọṣẹ́ náà:

We must not forget, my lord, that the chairman of this kangaroo probe is the Personnel Manager's in-law who works in the Establishment.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: A ògbọdọ̀ gbàgbé, olúwa à mi, pé alága ìgbìmò ìwádìí arúmọjẹ yìí tí ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ níi léeṣẹ́ yìí jẹ́ àna alákòóso òṣiṣẹ́ iléeṣẹ́ yìí.

The secretary is his cousin, the other two members are relations of the Personnel Manager’s friend.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìbátàn rẹ ni akọ̀wé, àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ méjì yòó kù sì jẹ́ ìbátan ọ̀rẹ́ alábòójútó òṣìṣẹ́.

That was why he found it easy to stage-manage things.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìdí nìyí tí ó fi rọrùn fún un látiṣé awúrúju yìí.

Ever since the beginning of this case, my lord, three of the defendant's key witnesses have absconded, the other witnesses are unreliable.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Láti ìgbà tí ẹjọ́ yìí ti bẹ̀rẹ̀, Olúwa à mi, mẹ́ta nínú àwọn ẹlẹ́rìí olújẹ́jọ́ yìí ni ó ti na pápá bora, àwọn elẹ́rìí yòókù kòṣé é gbáralé.

They are the Personnel Manager’s praise singers and professional congratulations, we have seen in this court how they fell, like a pack of cards under frank and honest cross-examination.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àwọn tó ń kọrin yin alákòóso òṣìṣẹ́ àti àwọn tó mọ ẹ̀pón àti ìkínikú-oríire ni wọ́n, a sì ti rí wọn nílé ẹjọ́yìí bí wọ́n ṣé fìdí rẹmi lábẹ́ àgbéyẹ̀wò tààrà, òdodo àti ìbéèrè ìwádìí.

My client. Mr. Alamu Olaoye has been made to suffer untold hardship and embarrassment as a result of the false allegation of dereliction of duty and financial mis-management levelled against him and the consequent illegal sack letter issued by the Personnel Manager of Bajoks Company Limited'.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Oníbàárà mi, ọ̀gbẹ́ni Àlàmú Ọláoyè ti jìyà àìmọ̀dí àti ìtìjú látàri irọ́ àìlèṣe ojúṣe-ẹni àti ìṣowó-kúmo-kùmo tí wọ́n pa mọ́ ọn, tí wọ́n sì fún un níwèé ìyọníṣẹ́ tí alábòójútó òṣìṣẹ́ iléeṣẹ́ Bajoks fún un.

The Personnel Manager’s move is a calculated attempt to eliminate my client from the Establishment and slot in his own man who had just graduated in Accountancy from the university and whose letter of application and C.V. are now resting in the Personnel Manager's office.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìgbésẹ̀ alábòójútó òṣìṣẹ́ wá látàrí ìṣirò ìpinnu rẹ̀ láti yọ oníbàárà mi níṣẹ́, kí wọ́n sì fi èèyàn tiwon tí óṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ kẹ́ kọ̀ọ́ gboyè nínú ìmọ̀ ìṣirò owó ní yunifásitì, tí àwọn lẹ́tà ìwáṣẹ́ rẹ̀ àti ẹ̀rí mo-kúnjú-ìwọn rẹ̀ ń bẹ lọ́fíìsì báyìí.

Conclusively, my lord, the good name of my client has been dragged into the mud, his reputation tamished. He has been painted black in the eyes the Managing Director, the overall boss of company.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Lákòótán, Olúwa à mi, wọn ti wọ́ orúkọ rere oníbàárà mi tuurutu nínú ẹrọ̀fọ̀, wọn ti bà á lórúkọ jẹ́, wọn ti bà á jẹ́ lójú a darí alábòójútó, tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀gá iléeṣẹ́.

I therefore pray the court to invoke the law to wrest my client from the vicious grip of his tormentors and oppressors.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Fún ìdí èyí, mo rọ ilé-ẹjọ́ yìí kí wọ́n fi òfin gba oníbàárà mi lọ́wọ́ àwọn ajunilo abatẹnijẹ́ yìí.

Some fifteen minutes later, the learned Judge  started reviewing the submissions of both the plaintiff and the defendant, finally pronouncing the verdict: wrongful termination of appointment of the Senior Accountant of Bajoks Company Limited, Mr. Alamu Olaoye. Action of the Personnel Manager, illegal.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Lẹ́yìn iṣéju mẹ́ẹ̀dógún, adájọ́ náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í ṣàtúnwò àwọn ẹ̀rí olùpẹjọ́ àti olùjẹ́jọ́, àti gbogbo àkọsílẹ̀ wọn, ìyọníṣẹ́ tó lòdì ni ti aṣírò-ọrọ̀ àgbà iléeṣẹ́ Bajoks, Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Àlàmú Ọláoyè, ìgbésẹ̀ alábòójútó òṣìṣẹ́, kò bófin mu.

The Managing Director of the company was not kept in the true picture of things. He had been deceived by his Personnel Manager.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Wọ́n kò sì fi àwòrán tòótọ́ bí ọ̀rọ̀ náà ṣe lọ han adarí alábòójútó iléeṣẹ. Alábòójú tóò ṣìṣẹ́ rẹ̀ ti tàn án.

Mr. Alamu Olaoye is therefore to be re-absorbed into the company as the Senior Accountant with immediate effect.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Kí Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Àlàmú Ọláoyè padà sínú iléeṣẹ́ náà gẹ́gẹ́ bí i aṣírò-ọrọ̀ àgbà ní kíá.

His nine-month salary is to be paid in arrears with immediate effect by the company, his annual incremental credit to be approved and effected.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Owó-oṣù rẹ̀ fún oṣù mẹ́sàn-án ni iléeṣẹ́ gbọ́dọ̀ san fún un ní kíákíá, àfikún owó rẹ̀ ọdọ ọdụ́n gbọ́dọ̀ gba òǹtẹ̀, kí ó sì gbà á.

A cost of five thousand naira to be paid as damages to Mr. Alamu Olaoye by the defendant.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ẹgbẹ̀rún márùn-ún náírà ni olùjẹ́jọ́ gbọ́dọ̀ san fun Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Àlàmú Ọláoyè fún ìbàjẹ́.

The attitude of the Personnel Manager is seen to be inimical to the progress and aspiration of a reputable company of Bajoks standing and the Managing Director is advised to institute a high powered inquiry into the activities of the Personnel Manager...’ That was how it all went.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìhùwàsí alábòójútó òṣìṣẹ́ lè dí ìlọsíwájú àti ọjọ́ iwájú iléeṣẹ́ Bajoks lọ́wọ́, fún ìdí èyí, mo gba a darí alábòójútó níì yánju láti ṣé ìwádìí tó mún ádọ́kọ sí gbogbo iṣé alábòójútó òṣìṣẹ́ náà... Bí ó ṣe lọ rè é.

That was how Lawyer Adio fought and finally won the legal battle for his friend. And now, what was left for them was to congratulate each other; then, at leisure, recapitulate the story leading up to this final victory.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Bí agbẹjọ́rò Àdìó ṣé ja àjàṣẹ́gun ogun olófin náà fún ọ̀rẹ́ rẹ̀. Nì báyìí, ohun tó ṣékù fún wọn ni láti kí ara wọn kúoríire, nìgbà tọ́wọ́ bá sì dilẹ̀, wọn ámáaṣé ìrántí ìtàn títí débi àjàṣẹ́gun rẹ̀.

There will be plenty of time later', Adio  repeated, ‘to tell all the story, for now, let's celebrate... and, what a way to begin the celebration! Adio pressed a button on his tape-recorder.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àsìkò á pọ̀ tó bá yá, Àdìó tún un sọ,”láti sọ gbogbo ìtàn  náà, ní báyìí jẹ́ kí a ṣàjọyọ̀...àti pé jẹ́ kí a bẹ̀rẹ̀ àjọyọ̀ náà báyìí! Àdìó tẹ bọ́tíìnì kan lára ẹ̀rọ ìgbohùnsílẹ̀ rẹ̀.

Alamu listened... A lady's voice full of complaints and bitterness came out loud. There was another voice - that of a man, occasionally intersecting.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àlàmú tẹ́tí... Ohùn obìnrin, tí ó kún fún ìfisùn àti ìbànújẹ́ jáde síta. Ohùn míì ǹ tún wà - ó jẹ́ ohùn ọkùnrin, tí ó ń ní igbe láàárín.

The dialogue between the two peony lasted for about five minutes, the female voice became more and more bitter and severe towards the end of the tape.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìtàkurọ̀sọ̀ láàárín èèyàn méjì pẹ́fún bí ìṣẹ́jú márùn-ún, ohùn obìnrin náà korò sí i, ó sì le ní òpin rẹ̀.

Labake's voice was unmistakable! Alamu instantly recognised the voice of his wife! No mistake about it...it quickly dawned on him that there was a fresh case to contest.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ohùn Làbákẹ́ òṣe é ṣì mú! Ẹṣẹ̀kẹṣẹ̀ ni Àlàmú  dá ohùn aya rẹ̀ mọ̀! Kò sí àṣìṣe nípa rẹ̀...ó tètè mọ̀ pé òun ní ẹjọ́ mìíràn láti rò.

This time, a matrimonial case, Labake was going to be the complainant, he was going to be the defendant. Anxiously he waited for the time he would come face to face with Labake.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ni àsìkò yìí, ẹjọ́ ìgbéyàwó wọn ni,  Làbákẹ́ á jẹ́ olùpẹjọ́, òun ni á jẹ́ olùjẹ́jọ́. Kò lè dúró de àsìkò tí yóò dúró lójúkojú pẹ̀lú Làbákẹ́.

That would be in a matter of five minutes or so from now. Adio’s car was waiting outside to take them away.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìyẹn á jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ iṣéju márùn-ún bí nǹkan sí ìsìnyí. Ọ̀kọ̀ ayọ́kẹ́lẹ́ Àdìó ń dúró níta láti gbé wọn lọ.

It was now three o'clock in the afternoon. Everything was quiet in Alamu's house.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Aago mẹ́ta ló lù báyìí lọ́sàn-án, gbogbo nǹkan ló dákẹ́ rọ́rọ́ ní ilé Àlàmú.

That was very unusual, the neighbours' curiosity was aroused, on other days the neighbours often listened as Alamu revved the old engine of his jalopy - disturbing their peace.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Èyí ṣàjèjì, Ọkàn ọ̀fintótó àwọn ará àdúgbò wọ́n wà lókè, ní àwọn ọjọ́ mìíràn, àwọn aládùúgbò yìí máa ń tẹ́tí sí bí Àlàmú ṣé ń ṣáná sí ẹ́ńjíìnì ọkọ̀ jalopí rẹ̀ – tí ó fi ń dà wọ́n láàmú.

They often listened to him yell out his strange outlandish laughter, and Labake blaring orders at Zenabu.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Wọ́n máa ń tẹ́tí sí bí óṣé ń rín ẹ̀rín aláruwo abàmì rẹ̀, àti bí Làbákẹ́ ṣé máa ń pariwo àṣẹ rẹ̀ fún Sènábù.

Tinu would be crying somewhere inside the house. There used to be movements too; like Labake rushing out to the market; Alamu hurriedly descending the stall case. backing the car out of the garage on his seemingly endless trips out to town; Tinu toddling about on the verandah of the house; Zenabu sneaking out to play with the other girls of her age group in the nearby house.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Tinú á máa sunkún níbì kan nínú ilé. Wọ́n máa ń gbọ́ ìgbésẹ̀ náà; bí i kí Làbáké ma lọ sọ́jà; bí i kí Àlàmú sáré máa bọ́lẹ̀ lórí àkàsọ̀ ilé. Kí ó sì fẹ̀yín ọkọ̀ rẹ̀ rìn kúrò nínú ọgbà ìgbọ́kọ̀sí sí ìrìnàjò aláìlópin rẹ̀ lọ sí ìgboro; Kí Tinú máa ṣére ní ọ̀dẹ̀dẹ̀ ilé wọn; Kí Sènábù máa yọ́ jáde láti báà wọn ọmọdébìnrin ẹgbẹ́ rẹ̀ ní àwọn ilé àyíká wọn.

But now, in Alamu's house, there was no noise and there was no movement, it has been like that morning - up till now - three o'clock in the afternoon.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ṣùgbọ́n nísinsìnyí, nílé Àlàmú, kò sí ariwo kankan, kò sí ìgbésẹ̀ kankan, ó  ti rí bẹ́ẹ̀ láti àáro –títí di ìsìnyí – aago mẹ́ta lọ́sàn-án.

That was strange, where was the mad man? Where was his mad wife? Where was that little rat they called their child? And the mischievous creature called Zenabu who used to give them first-hand accounts of what went on inside this mad house?
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Ìyẹn ṣàjèjì, níbo ni wèrè ọkùnrin wà? Wèrè ìyàwó rẹ̀ dà? Eku kékeré tí wọ́n pè lọ́mọ wọn dà? Àti ìkà ẹ̀dá tí wọ́n ń pè ní Sènábù, tí ó máa ń fún wọn ní ìròyìn tí ò lábùlà nǹkan tí ó ń lọ nínú ilé wèrè yìí?

If the neighbours had access to Alamu's house, they would have seen that Zenabu was still deep in sleep - by the side of a small load inside the sitting room of the house.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Bí àwọn aládùúgbò bá ní àǹfààní sí ilé Àlàmú, wọ́n á ti rí i pé Sènábù ṣì ń sùn lẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ ẹrù kékerénínú yàrá ìgbafẹ́ nínú ilé.

They would have seen that little Tinu was still in peaceful slumber in her mother's room in the house, the neighbours would have seen that Labake herself had just woken up, yawning and stretching her body after a sleepless night...
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Wọn ò bá ti rí i pé Tinú kékeré sì ń sun oorun àlàáfíà nínú yàrá ìyá rẹ̀ nínú ilé, àwọn aládùúgbò ò bá rí i pe Làbákẹ́ fún rarẹ̀ ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ jí, ó ń yán, ó ń nara lẹ́yìn alẹ́ àìsùn...

As the inquisitive neighbours continued gazing intently and pointing fingers, a white Mercedes-Benz zoomed in and jerked to a stop in front of Alamu’s house. Alamu came out of the car, another man following closely after him.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Bí àwọn èké àdúgbò ṣe ń wò lemọ́ lemọ́ tí wọ́n ń nàka, ni ọkọ̀ ayọ́kẹ́lẹ́ mẹ̀sí ọlọ́yẹ funfun kan wọlé, tí ó sì paná níwájú ilé Àlàmú. Àlàmú jáde nínú ọkọ̀ náà, ọkùnrin mìíràn sì tẹ̀lé e pẹ́kí pẹ́kí.

Together they ascended the stairs talking and nodding excitedly.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Àwọn méjèèjì jọ gun àkàsọ̀ ilé náà, wọ́n ń sọ̀rọ̀, wọ́n sì ń kanrí mọ́lẹ̀ tì dùnnú tì dùnnú.

Inside the sitting room, Alamu and his companion met Labake and saw that Zenabu was Just waking up from sleep.
Ọ̀rọ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nísinsìnyí yàtọ̀: Nínú yàrá ìgbàlejo, Àlàmú àti ẹnìkejì rẹ̀ pàdé Làbákẹ́, wọ́n sì rí i pé Sènábù ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ń jí láti ojú oorun ni.

The little girl scrambled up stretched and rubbed her face several times, she looked round and round - apparently to find out whether or not she was already in Kwara!
